text: hi everyone anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
silver mountain zion record
[ __ ] off get free we pour light on
everything
these guys are a montreal rock outfit
known for their connections to the
seminal post rock band
godspeed you black emperor there are
connections but there are also
differences for one the band invites
singing
and lyrics onto its records much to the
disappointment of some
hardcore godspeed fans who aren't really
that into the singing of frontman
ephraim menak whose voices a bit of an
acquired taste
however i wouldn't say these changes are
so great that it would keep a post rock
fan from enjoying
silver mount zion's first two records at
least early on in the band's music they
were sort of emphasizing the more
orchestral side of their sound
the more instrumental side of their
sound but since then with
each new release they have been evolving
into more of a rock music style and even
though guitars and drums have been more
of a
loud heavy driving force on silver mount
zion's past few records
this new one of theirs [ __ ] off get free
is definitely
the most fully realized and developed so
far in terms of this
heavier more aggressive sound the band
sound on this record is super
heavy distorted guitars piled on top of
one another to the point where
the first track on here sort of develops
this overwhelming
fuzziness warmth it becomes kind of
psychedelic too as these string sections
are swimming through this sea of guitars
and the instruments on this track they
blare so loudly it's impossible for this
song
not to be loud even when you turn it
down you could shut the door
but it's still gonna sound like
bombshells are dropping outside
the last third of this track even
introduces these slow
booming guitar riffs that feel slightly
akin to doom metal
and in this more chaotic stage in silver
mount zion sound on this record
ephraim's vocals don't sound half bad
i'm not saying his singing has gotten
way better but i think his vocals are a
bit more digestible sitting on this
bonfire of
burning guitars and bowed strings now
given that this band is godspeed related
and some of the lps that have come out
previously from silver mount zion
you might listen to this track expecting
something that is a bit more subtle
or dynamic or refined but the band
actually puts their all into just
creating this hulk of a track i can't
wrap my ears around it i can't wrap my
arms around it
it just rolls so slowly it bulldozes
everything in its way
passionately i love the group vocals on
this track the eerie melodies
the dramatic string sections that
introduce themselves in the last three
minutes
and the finisher of this track too is
pretty chilling i think
the singing some of the group vocals are
a little overbearing and somewhat goofy
occasionally but this is a great start
to this lp and to me the album just gets
better from here
austerity blues a song that tempo wise
is
really mid-paced but one of the more
aggressively performed
on this album it really sounds like the
band is jamming on these riffs that
they've written
instrumentally the band takes pretty
much that same all heavy
all-powerful approach really direct
really explosive but the band still
manages to incorporate elements that
make the song feel detailed cinematic
really vivid and even when the track
really picks up and
gets loud as hell the band manages to
make things even louder and more intense
as they introduce some
group vocals into the mixture at like
the eight minute mark this really raises
the energy level the refrain that
they're singing is incredibly
impassioned
and like many explosive moments on
godspeed and silver mount zion records
sometimes the
aftermath is just as moving with
just everything simultaneously coasting
down the guitars fading away the strings
and the vocals kind of
driving the track home here the strings
and the drums are so
sparse the vocals feel so weary the band
continues down this really immediate
path
on the next track to take away these
early grave blues
and even though silver mount zion had
tracks on their previous records that
landed around in this six or seven
minute mark
this is easily one of the most volatile
tracks that they've put out
within that time frame again the guitars
are blaring
the bass grooves are so steady on this
thing and sound like they came out of a
bad acid trip
and the lyrics here don't mince words
either and are delivered with
very unpleasant shouting take away these
take away these take away these
early grave blues as far as a lyrical
structure the song does take a lot of
influence from blues but i don't see a
lot of
connections being drawn to that genre
outside of that in the title because a
lot of the
melodies the string melodies that pop up
in between these verses feel
almost middle eastern in a sense and the
song grows more dissonant and chaotic as
it continues with all these
malformed strings and sour notes
floating within this wall of sound
it's just a really rebellious and
immense song
the melodies on this lp take a more
sad yet uplifting and tender direction
on the track what we loved was not
enough still a very heavy song but
emotionally potent as well a track with
what i assume is a 3-4 time signature
it's it's kind of like the waltz to end
all waltzes
the song features all these really
teary-eyed string sections vocals that
just
yelp out these frighteningly morbid
lyrics that are sort of carried by the
phrase
the day has come where we no longer feel
there will be war in our cities there
will be riots at the mall
blood on our doorsteps and panics at the
ball all our city's gonna burn
all our bridges gonna snap all our penny
is gonna rot
lightning roll across the tracks all our
children
gonna die it's a cataclysmic track that
the more i listen to it the more it just
grabs me
and just shakes me emotionally obviously
and the only slight letdown of this
entire lp
is the closing song which i do think is
slightly
underwhelming short of breath it feels
more like an epilogue
honestly if this song had just been
erased the last track would have been a
somewhat fitting closer but
i do think that this song is added on to
add on to the themes of this album that
have to do with
end times people dying in
their younger years early graves
premature
death dying before you even reach the
point of
adulthood this may have to do with the
fact that this song in the title
says it's a tribute to capital steez
with all the refrains mentioning
children dying on the previous track and
the early great blues on this record
this does seem to be a recurring theme
on [ __ ] off get free and even though i
think that a lot of the lyrics on this
record are incredibly
flowery there is something that is
really moving about how blunt
and direct silver mount zion is with its
messages
i was hoping for a little bit more from
the ending here
but i guess in a way and i'm just sort
of interpreting this on a personal level
it does bring home the idea that when
the ending comes
it's not necessarily something that
holds your hand it doesn't necessarily
give you an explicit warning
it arrives when it feels like it much to
our surprise despite
that we may be making our own beds
i'm feeling a strong eight to a light
nine on this record
tran position if you've given this thing
a listen what did you think of it
love it hate it why what do you think i
should review next
and that's it anthony fantano
silvermouth zion [ __ ] off get free
forever
